New Mural Brightens SMS Science Hallway

Even though our hallways were empty for five months, Sullivan Middle School did not stop preparing for the day students would return. On top of the deep cleaning and floor waxing that is part of every summer here at Sullivan Schools, there was one very special project taking place on the second floor. The brainchild of Mr. Troy Rogers and parent volunteer Megan Harden, the mural stretches for nearly 50 feet, from floor to ceiling, down the Science Hallway. Multiple teachers assisted with the effort, coming in on a rotation basis to help get paint on the wall to help Harden's design come to life. There are plans to populate the bottom half of the mural with aquatic life later in the school year.

Breakfast of Champions: Trey Fleming, nominated by Mrs. Isaacs
I nominated Trey for several reasons. First of all, he is a prime example of why I love my job. I have had the pleasure of watching Trey grow so much over the past four years. Thinking back to his freshman year and seeing where he is now, is amazing! It just amazes me when I overhear him tell under-class men how important it is to use their time wisely and to get their homework done on time. Also, math has never been Trey’s favorite class. I think he might have rather had a tooth pulled than do a math assignment. This year he has been a role model for my students struggling in math and has even volunteered to assist them with their assignments. As I work with students throughout their four years of high school, I am sometimes worried about them struggling in the “real world”. That is in not the case with Trey. I know through our conversations and his actions, that he is ready for “adulting”. When I say I am going to miss him, I truly do mean it!

Breakfast of Champions: Beau Fleming, nominated by Ms. Hoijer
Beau has really gone above and beyond in geometry class this semester! Beau’s curiosity, ingenuity, and cleverness set him apart. He is never satisfied with “good enough” and will always go the extra mile to analyze the “why” or the “how” of any given problem. In geometry, there is often more than one way to solve a problem or put together a proof, and Beau looks at the problem from every possible angle. In class a couple of weeks ago, we were working on challenge angle puzzles, and Beau completed not one, not two…but all three of these challenges, including the most rigorous Mega-Challenge puzzle! Even more impressive, he had them all completed before the end of the day. Beau came to my classroom during Advisory later that same day with a big grin on his face and all three puzzles completed flawlessly! That continuous drive and thirst for knowledge is admirable and will lead Beau to success!

Quarterly, using a "Breakfast of Champions," Sullivan High School celebrates students for the following :
• Students who have made a drastic turn-around academically, or behaviorally.
• Students who exhibit great school spirit/pride and show it in the classroom, hallways, and extra-curricular activities
• Students who regularly meet/exceed expectations.
• Student leaders (who lead quietly by example, or are more visible/outright in their leadership capacities)
• Students who intentionally go out of their way to help other students .
Since we could not hold a "Breakfast of Champions" in the 3rd quarter, we will be honoring the students who were nominated over the next several days by posting what their nominating teacher said about them along with their picture.
